text: [Music]
right well I you know again I'm a
practicing psychiatrist and I think that
I really believe in the advance as of
Psychiatry our diagnoses are more uh
precise uh they get more precise with
every volume of the diagnostic manual
our treatments slowly get better over
time um and I'm not verse to saying that
there are biological bases to mental
illness I'm uh part of a department that
does a lot of fantastic research in
brain Imaging um scans other kinds of
genetic research that really looks at
mental illness seemingly below the level
of culture context race ethnicity at the
level of brain structures that are
seemingly the same in all people and at
the same time I feel like there's a
false divide almost like you have to
vote
is an illness biological or is it social
or socially constructed and and I I
don't like that divide very much because
I think that all definitions of illness
and maybe particularly all definitions
of psychiatric illness are always are
always both it doesn't have to be one or
the other mental illness is a real thing
it has real material consequences for
people who suffer from it and at the
same time even the most biological
finding reflects social uh social
context in very important ways and so I
think Psychiatry is better off looking
both at biology and at Social context
and really trying to think of the
relationship between those and I think
doctors and patients are better off that
way um we certainly know that depression
is an
illness all you have to do is watch an
anti-depressant advertisement on
television right now and think about why
might it be that a person might see an
ad like that what are the forces that
are leading them to go in and ask a
doctor in part
um in part it might be that that ad
speaks to some symptoms they're having
that are chemical symptoms but you many
of these ads play off of familiar
cultural stereotypes about gender or
parenting or social class other kinds of
things and so I think doctors need to be
aware both that depression as one
example is an illness that has a a
chemical basis but also is deeply
embedded in cultural norms about gender
social class race um so that would be
one example there's great work that's
been done now on bipolar disorder by
Emily Martin here at NYU and looking at
the kind of cultural basis of of bipolar
disorder um obsess some compulsive
disorder after the show monk for
instance is something that there's a lot
of popular conversation about and so I
think again it's true for all Illness
but it's certainly true for psychiatric
illness that these illnesses often
reflect cultural norms in addition to
biological realities and really we have
to be fluent in in
both well again I I think that we're
we're making a mistake if we don't see
that there's a cultural basis
to many illnesses not just psychiatric
ones breast cancer would be one
prevalent example right now different
kind of culture surrounding it if you
don't understand the cultural meaning of
in illness like that you're going to
you're going to miss the boat even if
you a great scientist um so I don't
think it's the case that it's just
psychiatric disorders but we know from
history that when we get the ultimate
you know cure for a particular illness
or nail it down it stops being a
psychiatric illness and then it's taken
up by internal medicine or you know we
know oh it's it was just an iron
imbalance or it was a vitamin deficiency
or something like that that anyway it's
taken away from Psychiatry and taken
taken to medicine but um but I think
that uh you know if you look at
diagnostic rates and treatment rates in
psychiatric disorders it's it's even
with all the controversy about ssris
right now um the the the Improvement
rates are are reasonably good compared
to other Medical Specialties and so I
think it's it's always going to be a
negotiation about what's the best way to
understand psychiatric Illness but of
course the flip side of that is that
there is this Aura of it's something we
don't know in a certain kind kind of way
and so Psychiatry is always kind of
fighting against that and probably
that's why we had a move toward saying
things are solely biological in a
certain kind of way is to you know
rightly move toward a more scientific
basis terrific well I mean it's it's
there are really exciting things
happening in genetics and neurobiology
right now and really looking at the ways
in
which different not just illnesses but
social conditions and social pressures
can actually lead to actual uh brain
changes um you know there was a lot of
Promise in the development of
pharmaceutical particularly with the
Advent of newer generation of anti
psychotics and anti- um depressants and
we know from history that there's a kind
of natural trajectory of the way that
these that these
medications um come out and and are
accepted so initially we say these are
cures for everything under the sun uh
and there's this dramatic rise and then
we say wait a minute these don't work
for anything which I think is happening
with the SSRI anti-depressants right now
and then we kind of figure out a
moderated use of well they're good for
some conditions and and not for others
and so again as I say I think that
there's
a a give and take that's part of the
process and part of it is based in
science but I also think you know the
1990s were often called the decade of
the brain in Psychiatry where we didn't
need to worry about Freud or about
gender psychoanalysis context all these
things were in certain ways kind of
pitched out the window because we were
going to get the answer to everything
from brain scans and I think Psychiatry
itself has come to in a way like
medications a more
moderated understanding of the brain
itself is very important but you don't
really know anything about the brain
unless you know about social context
expectations stigmas other kinds of
things and so hopefully these findings
will continue to be tood in in Social
context
